inn1.comm: a no-ball to start with, fullish and dug out into the covers

(almost) perfect start for new Zealand. A soft dismissal, short outside off stump, almost a long hop, which Joyce swishes at and gets a thin but audible top edge to and McCullum flings the ball high. An easy catch and a real sucker punch
outside off stump, Bell shoulders arms
another no-ball, played into the covers.
sweetly clipped through midwicket, that would have been four but the outfield is very wet and as a result the chasing fielders caught up just inside the rope
good response, angled across Vaughan who played inside the line. Lots of chirping and clapping from the close fielders
a touch wider and that one also kept low - a hint of uneven bounce - and Vaughan never interested
full on off stump, driven firmly to mid-off

lovely ball ... just short of a length, ripped back a good 18 inches off the pitch and hit Bell on the pads as he shouldered arms. Way too high for an appeal but that will raise doubts in the batsmen's minds
Bell forward to block a fuller-length delivery
good length with late inswing, Bell flicks it a few feet in front of of the man at short backward square leg
Bond probing away, less swing and Bell blocks
Bond strays to the off and Koertzen calls a wide, which looked rather harsh. It was marginal at best and there will be far worse to come which won't be called ...
whipped into the leg side, a loud and clear shout of "No" from Bell
Bond again strays to the off side and incurs the wrath of Koertzen
better line, just outside off stump and Bell half-heartedly fences at it and misses
slanted across Vaughan, wide and got wider and a much more straightforward decision
back on the button, Vaughan right into line to block
outside off stump, another one that kept a bit low, and Vaughan jabs it into the covers
leggish, Vaughan sways inside the line and runs it off his hips down to long leg
Bell turned a bit squareish as he gets into line to defend
Bell takes a couple of steps to meet the ball, it's straight and he adjusts to block it
good line and once more Bell forced into a defensive stroke
a grunt from Bond as he fires the ball in short outside the off stump
Vaughan back into line as the balls jags back into him. Bond is combining swing and seam really well here, not letting either batsman settle
too short outside the off stump and Vaughan shoulders arms
same line and length -  a fraction short and 10-12 inches outside the off stump. Vaughan leaves it alone
Vaughan felt for that as it held its line and the ball zipped past the outside edge
Vaughan back and plays that into the covers
Full and wide, Bell reaches for the ball and steers it down to third man
slanted across the right hander who half leaves, half spars at it
Vaughan walks to meet a full delivery and plays it back to Franklin on the bounce. Franklin shapes as if he is about to throw it back at Vaughan but thinks better of it
driven not that hard to mid-off
Vaughan forward, the ball finds the outside edge and scoots along the ground past the diving second slip, Patel scurries round to third man to field
an ill-timed cover drive which hardly reached mid-off
outside the right hander's off stump and no shot
played with an open face into space square on the off
short outside the off, Vaughan on that very quickly and pulled in front of square to the midwicket boundary. That was the first shot of confidence and authority from Vaughan
punched into the covers off the back foot but not timed
Vaughan takes a step, steers the ball to point and sets off for a quick single, but Bell send him back very quickly
defensive push into the off side
yorker-length outside off stump, Bell tries to squeeze the ball down to third man but misses
Bell back and looks to flick that to the leg side, misses, and the ball pops up off his pads into space on the off side. Not what he intended but the same end result
another no-ball, and that's six wides and no-balls to date
expansive leave from Vaughan
one step forward and to the off, and that enables him to whip the ball into the leg side through midwicket
super shot, the best of the brief session so far. A half-volley, driven straight back down the pitch and all along the ground
too much width and Vaughan angles that to wide third man
Vaughan stands on his toes and punches that straight to cover
outside the off stump and Vaughan misses with a rather indeterminate swish
firmly driven hard at Vettori at mid-off and loud shouts of "wait" from both ends
plopped into the covers but no run
slightly slower and full, driven between cover and extra cover
Bell drives to mid-off and Bond scowls as he turns to begin his journey down to long leg
slightly stiff-looking loosener outside off stump
wide, driven a bit uppishly to the left of a diving point, but despite the calls of "catch" it was wide and short of him
Vaughan steps to the off but Oram sees him moving and follows him with the ball.
whipped behind square on the leg side

Oram strikes, Bell tried to drive a ball that was a little too wide and a little too short, and the thin edge is easily taken by McCullum. Bell got a bit bogged down there and frustration appeared to have got the better of him
jabs down on a full delivery
Vaughan feels at one outside the off stump, no foot movement, and the ball scoots through at knee height
Vaughan waits and steers the ball safely down to third man
rather loose drive to cover, well hit but not placed
full and leg-stump line, Pietersen has to hurry to pat it back to the bowler
Pietersen defensively drives to mid-off

Pietersen dead bats the ball into the off side and momentarily looks as if he is about to set off for a single, a movement which worries Vaughan more than the fielders and his shout of "no" has a hint of desperation about it
Vaughan plays that defensively into the covers
pushed into the covers and a quick shout ensures an easy single, a diving stop by Lou Vincent ensures there is no second. That was 76mph ...
on the walk, Pietersen gets a thick inside edge into his thigh and the ball pops into the off side as the fielders converge
tidy line and length, all at around 75-77mph, and Pietersen watchfully defends
an attempted off drive, but Pietersen again finds a thick inside edge and the ball scurries to midwicket

Vaughan escapes what should have been a certain run-out. Pietersen drove straight to mid-on but called for the single leaving Vaughan stranded as Vettori picked it up and threw from a prone position to McCullum with the England captain all at sea. The throw was not great but McCullum missed it. Poor cricket all round ...
yorker dug out into the off side
worked into the on side, a massive cry of "no" as Pietersen sniffed for a second
on middle, played from the crease with a straight bat
forced off the back foot, Bond fielded in his follow through
Vaughan toe-ends an attempted pull and the ball goes nowhere.  He is struggling to time the ball with any regularity
safely patted back to Bond
a massive shout for a catch behind from Oram and a delayed one from McCullum as Pietersen drives and misses. Good decision
turned on the walk to Taylor at short midwicket
outside the off stump and left alone
an on drive which Pietersen barely seemed to hit, a big stride across his stumps and perfectly timed straight back to the right of the bowler
punched to mid-on and a loud shout of "no" from Pietersen as Vaughan set off for the single
Pietersen stands tall on his toes and drives elegantly right at short extra cover
Vaughan back and flicks the ball from off stump to mid-on
driven on the half-volley a couple of yards short of mid-on, again from off stump
a rather wild swish to a ball outside off stump
and that's just what he has done! Full, and driven sweetly up and over mid-on and it races to the rope
mistimed pull - not the first of the day - and the ball plops into the leg side for a single
Pietersen again takes two steps to meet the ball, Franklin responds by firing it in at his feet and he has no option but to block it
turned to the right of mid-on for an ambled single
slightly slower ball deceives Pietersen who drives at air and he walks towards Oram with a grin that says "you did me"
steered to point and a quick shout of "no"
lovely stuff from Pietersen. He came down the pitch to drive but it wasn't there and he quickly adjusted and flicked the ball fine down the leg side. Real class
two strides and a trademark flick over midwicket with his back leg in the air. Two decent balls and two boundaries. Who'd be a bowler?
driven to mid-off, a subdued end to an entertaining over
driven straight to mid-on without much power
dabbed down to third man
awful shot and Vaughan pays the price. The ball wasn't short enough to pull, but Vaughan tried to, and instead dragged a huge bottom edge back into his stumps. England now wobbling a touch here
Collingwood away immediately with a well-timed shot, just a caress really, in front of midwicket
far from vintage ball - overstepping, that's short and down leg too, and tucked off the hips square
worked to mid-off and the batsmen are safely through after Vettori returns the ball easily enough
driven to cover
right on the money and that's defended on the back foot
driven slowly to mid-on for a comfortable single
slice of luck for the batsman there - that one is short and wide of off-stump, asking to be cover-driven; a thick inside edge instead and the ball runs to fine leg
tucked into the covers
good ball, that - line and length were spot-on, but the batsman did well to judge that, shouldering arms as it slinked through to McCullum
dabbed down to short third man
tidy ball, dealt with through a nibble into the off-side
across the righthander, straight and short and Pietersen stands tall, driving to mid-on but doesn't quite get  hold of the ball
on to the back foot and that's worked into the off-side softly
driven into the covers, but straight to the fielder
slower ball, well dug out and that's eased into the covers
well defended
driven straight back past the bowler to long-on where the man drops off from mid-on to chase the ball down
on the money, defended well and does McCullum think that was a decent ball? "Yes, Jake, yes, Jake."
ooh, nearly out again. The cut shot nearly proves fatal once more - chopping that forcefully right down into the ground past off-stump and nutmegging McCullum in the process
change of pace for Oram, but Pietersen is quickly on to it with a sturdy defence
strides forward to guide that into the leg side, there was nearly a mix-up, but Pietersen sent Collingwood back
slower ball, driven slowly straight and it's snapped up easily
pushed up there and defended off the back foot into the off side
across the righthander who defends again
across again, but slightly too wide, gets away with it, though, as it was a pretty tidy length and that's just driven slowly into the covers
worked off the front foot into the midwicket region
on a good line and length and that's merely driven to mid-on where it's picked up easily

dropped! Ooh, Pietersen could have been a gonner then - short and smashed away through cover - but aerially and Vincent got a hand to it. A really hard one for Vincent, that, who made the most of it - turning it into a chance in fact with a low, sharp dive at full stretch - but nevertheless will go down as an opportunity
gets turn immediately with one which pitches outside off and comes back in, gently enough, to the righthander who deals with it tidily
up there, defended with a stout prod, showing the full face of the bat, into the short midwicket region
down on one knee and tries to sweep that from outside off to the leg side, misses, and the ball clatters into him
dances down the track and whirls the ball from outside off to leg, but doesn't have much power in that shot
on off and that's worked to leg again
turned that one into him and it's worked to leg
huge shout immediately for lbw - it was certainly straight enough, but Pietersen got a big stride in and perhaps his gum-chewing nonchalance was a further clue to help the umpire
swept round off the pads to the 45
the Kiwis' lungs getting a good workout here - another throaty roar, but that was well outside the line
driven out through the covers now
worked into the midwicket region
driven out to long-off this time and there's a quick strike-stealing single for Collingwood
short, and cut away down to backward point
well worked by the batsman, rolling his wrists over the ball and turning it quickly to square
worked into midwicket
a hint of aggression, walking down the track and driving that in front of midwicket, but it's straight to a fielder
a touch of flight on that one but it's whisked through midwicket
pitches outside off and pops up a touch at the batsman who wasn't expecting it, but adjusts well, to go back on the balls of his feet, and pokes it into short midwicket
outside off, but on a good length, and that's well left alone
comes forward with a very deliberate prod forward
driven slowly to long-on for just the single
flight and that falls on a nagging length, Collingwood having no other option than to stifle the bounce
Collingwood shuffles forward to one which drifts in at him and he eases it into the midwicket region
driven out to the cover boundary
a leading edge - but flies into space - Pietersen just working with the spin, there, and it's his turn to nick the strike
poor from Pietersen, creeping down the pitch before it was even delivered. Patel saw him coming and pitched it fuller and he managed to completely miss it
chipped into the leg side, between the in- and the outfield
Pietersen giving him the charge again, working against the drift to flick that aerially into leg
Pietersen takes just the one stride this time, driving it straight to long-on
more positivity from the batsman, this one a drive to long-on
slower ball, well placed, and Collingwood can only defend
saw Pietersen coming and varied the delivery, forcing the batsman to defend. Good spot
gets right over the ball and defends
shorter ball, with a touch of width outside off and Pietersen waits for it, before caressing it to the covers
defended forward
driven off the toes to midwicket
driven to midwicket and that's tidied up nicely by the fielder with a rolling stop
comes forward, a touch of flamingoing from Pietersen as he stand firmly on the one foot to whip that with strong wrists in front of midwicket
turns into the righthander, but down the wrong line and the batsman works that easily into the leg side
drags that a touch short, but the turn is enough to pose a problem, and that's just defended on the back foot in the end
well flighted and there's a wristy whip but without much power (it's a slow track, remember) to mid-on
ooh, good thinking from Patel - slower, wider, a touch of curve and Pietersen - like a naughty boy who finds his Christmas presents early - is tempted. Gets away with it
leading edge looking to chip the ball over the fielder at midwicket - such was the timing of that shot that even though it wasn't cleanly struck it went high enough and cleared mid-on
outside off, a touch of width, and that's cut off the back foot out to point
driven easily to long-on for a tidy single
tries a slower one, dropping that outside off, but with enough width for the batsman to cut that easily
fuller, but too full this time, and that's languidly eased to mid-on
oh, inside edge this time, but flies wide of the stumps for a quick single
worked to square
hello! Massive! As Mark Nicholas would say, he's a big strong boy, and that's whipped over long-on - he didn't even time it properly but it still travelled
driven to long-on this time
Collingwood the aggressor this time - striding forward and driving that over the top through cover
on to the back foot and pushes that into cover
short, but straight and popping up, and Collingwood deals with that by prodding it into the leg side
comes forward, gets right over the ball with a defensive jab into the off side
gets over the spin and flaps it in front of midwicket
pitches outside off and that's nurdled behind point
driven to mid-on
pushed up there and defended
defended once more
some glove punching results from Collingwood's aerial sweep - he took a step down and hoisted that through midwicket. Nice
gentle and full (69mph), driven hard back at Styris who fields with foot and leg
clipped up to long-on for a mutually agreed single, so nobody breaks sweat
driven past cover and as Patel runs in there is a shout of "no, not to him"
Pietersen gets caught a bit square on and he can only run the ball back to the bowler
crisp drive between cover and extra cover, and even the zippy Patel charging round from sweeper cannot prevent the two, runs which bring up Pietersen's fifty, and the applause is warm
Pietersen blocks
Styris keeps the ball up in the blockhole and for once Pietersen is content to block
square drive to backward point
cracking backfoot drive to the sweeper
Pietersen comes down the pitch and Vettori waits, leaving the batsman standing like a spurned teenager mid pitch, and when the ball eventually arrives he clips it to mid-on with a grin
another slower ball which is blocked. Great variation of speed
driven back to Vettori who makes a sprawling stop
circumspect forward defensive
pushed down the ground to long-on

down the leg side and McCullum brilliantly whips the bails off and races away celebrating. It's so close and it takes the third umpire several replays and a swig of gin before he rules in the batsman's favour ... but it was mighty close and was really slick keeping. And after all that, it's just a wide
firm drive to short midwicket
a tad short outside off stump, and again Pietersen cannot beat the man at short midwicket
Pietersen waits, smacks that towards long-on and strolls the single
clipped a little uppishly to short midwicket. A shout of catch but not in this world
for the fourth time short midwicket attracts the ball as if it was a magnet
Pietersen rocks back and cuts that behind point, Ross Taylor chases and flings himself to scoop the ball back on the rope
Collingwood steps back, waits and works that behind square on the leg side
Pietersen takes two or three steps down the pitch and chips it over the in field to long-on
another cut behind square on the off, this time that gap has been plugged and it's just the one
two steps but Vettori fires one in wide and all the batsman can do is drive the ball back at him
Pietersen waits and punches the ball through the covers for the single that keeps him on strike
short of a length and pushed through the gap in the covers
Collingwood waits and whips the ball into the leg side
premeditated scoop from outside off stump behind square on the leg side
dropped a return catch high to Styris's left, he got both hands to it but was a bit late and he could only parry the ball
paddled on the off but point quickly in to save the single

Collingwood shapes to run the ball down to third man but only succeeds in running it off the face of the bat right into McCullum's gloves. He leaps towards the heavens as if stung by a bee as his colleagues race in to celebrate
On off stump and blocked
Pietersen leans back and hammers that at extra cover. A yard either side and that would have been four ...

a soft end to a good innings. Pietersen took a stride down the pitch and chipped the ball to James Franklin coming in from long-on. It was a lame stroke, a nothing stroke, and now England are in the deep stuff
Dalrymple forced back by an effort ball
short and at the body, Dalrymple paddles the ball round to long leg

a collapse turns into a crisis for England. A slower ball and Flintoff does no more than chip the ball to extra cover who takes the most routine of routine catches. New Zealand are almost beside themselves as Flintoff, head bowed, trudges off
on the spot and a cautious block
Dalrymple again watches and blocks
squirted out on the off side. Dalrymple needs to consolidate and he won't take any risks for a few overs
worked round the corner to long leg. Nixon takes guard ...
a rather uncertain push through the covers and they come back for two as the man in the deep is a little too casual. Styris gives a death stare
controlled edge to short third man
Dalrymple prods without any foot movement and misses
on off stump at 83mph, Dalrymple back to defend one that came in a fraction
outside off stump - accompanied by a loud grunt - and Dalrymple leaves the ball
deliberate steer to third man
yorker, on the boot, loud and confident appeal, but possibly just outside the line of off stump. Nixon was beaten all ends up. Koertzen ponders and then makes what  replays show was a good decision
pushed to mid-off and a moment of yes-no calling before both men decide to stay right where they are
played out to point. McCullum in full chirrup mode
an attempted steer to third man and McCullum is airbourne as, standing up, he takes a thin edge and Dalrymple is on his way. Great keeping and excellent, nagging bowling
uncertain defensive prod which squirms into the leg side
on the spot again. Styris is in full control here
Nixon forward to push the ball back to the bowler
Nixon back and cuts the ball into space on the off side. Sensible batting as he has to keep as much of the strike as possible
good shot, Nixon waits and guides the ball behind square on the off and Patel racing round from sweeper cannot stop it
Nixon back, he jabs down and keeps the ball out
banged in, Nixon tries to pull but doesn't time it, hits it into the ground and has to settle for the single
a slower ball and a Sharipovaesque grunt, but even so the ball almost scoots along the ground. If it had been on target then Plunkett would have been in the mire
this was was on line but Plunkett was equal to it
another slower ball, this one a yorker, but again Plunkett read it
Nixon back and runs the ball down to third man
back and drops the ball into the ground
full, patted into the leg side
good line, naggingly accurate, and Plunkett again defends
"Good mate," notes McCullum. And he's right. On target and stifling
Plunkett aims to hit to leg, misses, and the ball wraps him on the pads and trickles to the off
Nixon back and into the off side, but point zooms in to prevent the single
fast and straight, checked drive to mid-off
a rather ungainly swing which goes nowhere
defensive push into the off side
turned to backward square leg
low full toss, turned to leg and Plunkett calls for and gets the single. The end of a really good spell (or two) from Bond
driven stylishly but utterly ineffectively to point
driven straight down the ground, well timed and placed, and Stryis could do nothing as it bisected him and mid-off
Plunkett took all the pace off the ball and that allowed the run to point
pushed gently to long-off
same again from Plunkett, soft hands take the pace off the ball and so allow the single even though it went right to point
Nixon back, waits, and then punches the ball to mid-off
Full, Nixon can only dig it out a few inches into the off side
improvised reverse sweep, not middled but it goes in generally the right direction
plopped into the off side
Plunkett waits and swats the ball into the covers
sweet drive past extra cover, long-on shuffles round to cut it off
whipped to midwicket
Nixon back and too cramped to get any power on his attempted cut
misses an attempted reverse sweep, and misses it by some way
full toss - almost a yorker -  driven down the ground
Plunkett takes two big steps and then blocks
again Plunkett comes to meet the ball and chips it over the infield, five yards short of long-on but never a catching chance
McCullum gets very excited but Nixon got bat on the ball and steered it to long leg
two steps from Nixon, who almost yorks himself in the process, but he jabs the ball to long-on
punched off the back foot to sweeper
Nixon skips down the pitch, gets in a muddle, but pads the ball past a diving McCullum
lovely use of the feet to meet the ball. No runs, but good practice for
that's better, again using his feet but this time he swings the ball back with interest and over the rope
another firm shot but Vettori dives to field off his own bowling
missed sweep, strangulated appeal, nothing doing
steered to Vettori in the deep on the off side
a mix-up, driven to wide midwicket and some "yes-no-oops" calling
prodded down the ground
driven wide of Patel, who dived full stretch to his right, but the ball just evaded his fingertips
turned to leg. A good over at this stage, only the four singles
good bowling, really cramping Plunkett
finally a reverse sweeps comes off, Nixon middled that and it raced away. Vettori scowls
tries the same again but this one is not middled and it bobbles away for a single
Vettori sees Plunkett dancing down the pitch and fires the ball in
driven into the gap in the covers, into the space created when Fleming moved a man to plug the area of the reverse sweep
worked into the leg side. Twelve off the over
Nixon steps to leg, Patel follows him, and the batsman has to be content with a push to long-off
a big cross-batted heave, not middled, and the ball scurries to deep midwicket

Nixon heaves and misses, a loud shout for leg-before is turned down, Plunkett wanted the single and both men almost ended up at the same end, the throw was wild and Patel wasn't behind the stumps, and there was almost an overthrow . In the end, no run!
another easy run into space
swishing drive to long-off. "That's brilliant, mate," yells McCullum
poor bowling, a no-ball from a spinner is never appreciated by his captain, and it was short  as well, Nixon thumping the ball through midwicket
Patel all at sea as Nixon swats a half volley straighter but wide of long-on. Nine runs off two balls ...
slow full toss driven down the ground, Nixon called for the second - he was running to the danger end - and he made it with a full-length dive
a swing and a big leading edge, the ball arcs down to third man, a few yards short of him
driven straight but not off the middle of the bat, and the ball barely makes it halfway to the rope
Nixon shimmies to the off and clips the ball wide of midwicket, Vincent slides just in front of the rope to save the four
slower ball, hammered right at midwicket
waist-high full toss hit right at extra cover

inn2.comm: stood tall and fished at that one with a straight bat, sending the lightest feather of an edge through to Nixon who snaps up an easy catch
left alone outside off stump
tried to flick that round to fine, a fumble from Nixon, and they scramble the leg bye
what a catch! Flintoff, diving athletically at wide first slip, takes a terrific catch, one handed with his right hand
left alone outside off stump - good line
less of a good line this time, but not a bad length and the batsman leaves it alone
fended into the covers
strays a touch too full and on leg and that's timed through mid-on beating a diving Michael Vaughan
straight and short and that's worked down off the back foot into the short midwicket area

a big shout for lbw. That one angles across the lefthander and comes back in a touch, but not enough for the umpire's liking. Oh, replays show just how close that one was. Fleming survives but the momentum's all with England
works his bat on that one late, pushing it to square leg for a quick single
wide and steered to second slip who makes a good stop. It was right at him but the ball was motoring
outside off stump and left alone
missed with an indifferent jab at one just outside off stump
driven to cover off the back foot
worked to midwicket again and that's good running
well bowled, going straight on to Styris who needs to jab his bat down at the last minute
drifting into the legs and that's just flicked away - a second boundary from Styris
right up there again and once more Styris, hopping, has to bring his bat down in defence
angling in at the righthander who drives it back out to cover
overpitched and Fleming walks into that one with an exceptionally elegant straight drive which cuts between the men at mid-off and mid-on
straight and squeezed to square leg
short and driven uppishly to point
angled across the lefthander whose drive makes the ball dribble to the cover region
driven straight to the man at extra cover

It's a great catch from Joyce over his head running backwards at deep midwicket. Anderson banged that one in short, Fleming's eyes lit up but he didn't get over the pull shot and he sent that high and higher - the ball hanging in the air for a while
short and that's defended down off the back foot
short, wide and that's lashed through cover, hunted down by Dalrymple just inside the boundary
a good line, and that's defended into the covers
short and sent aerial over to the point boundary where Panesar makes a rare fumble, fluffing his long barrier and New Zealand scramble the second
right up there and that's driven to mid-on
driven down the ground on the off side - a crashing shot - and there's no need to run for that!
banged down short, wide, and it's help-yourself time. Styris latches on to it and bunts it with sweet timing off the back foot in front of point
fuller and straighter and the batsman can only defend down off the back foot
turned off the legs at about knee height through square
defended down
looked to drive on the up and the ball just sticks in the surface as that goes to Pietersen in the covers who stops it, although not tidily
good shot - short and whipped through midwicket off the back foot with a great pull
short, on leg, and that's worked easily in front of midwicket
tucked off the hips on the front foot to short midwicket
a big whoosh - trying to cart that one from outside off up through midwicket. Completely missed it all
on the money, angling in at the lefthander, who moved it into the short midwicket
a huge appeal from Flintoff - two hands and everything - but it was a late one and indeed there was a big inside edge there
in at the pads and that's worked behind square off the pads
a big cheer from the England fans, but a premature one, as Styris's shot was a huge bump ball but it looked to have carried to Collingwood at cover. Ah, the deceptiveness of appearances
left alone outside off
defended in front
too short and that's swivel-pulled through wide mid-on, Vaughan chasing it down inside the rope
fended to point
short and worked to the covers
overstepping - a rare no-ball from Flintoff. That flies through the channel and Styris leaves it alone
angles in at the righthander and that's defended with a stout bat, the batsman standing tall
same ball, same result - solid defence
short, coming in again at the righthander, and defended on the back foot into the short midwicket region
driven softly to mid-on and the ball rolls along the ground
in at the righthander, strays on leg a touch and that's driven to mid-on
right up there, pad first, and there's a half-shout for lbw
driven to mid-off
dragged down short and that's picked off in front of midwicket with an easy, crashing pull shot
short and that's driven on the up to cover
strays on to leg with that one which is rushed in front of square and they think about the second one, but decide not to take it
driven to point where there's some good ground fielding
a touch of width and the batsman does well to guide that one down to fine leg
on a good spot and McMillan can only defend that one into the covers
a good area again and this time it's another quiet defence
good rhythm from Flintoff; he hits the same spot, the batsman defends and again there's "No!" run
impressive stuff - there once more and there's an inevitable defensive shot into the covers
picked off the hips out to deep square leg
short and that's slashed behind point to Panesar inside the boundary
short, McMillan moves backward to give himself room to swing his arms and lash the ball through cover where Anderson's nutmegged - but he just manages to stop the ball within the boundary
short, straight and McMillan tries to give himself room again to cut that off the back foot - he plays over it, though and Nixon picks up the through-ball
slower ball drifts on to leg and that's just tickled round - a dab, really - behind square
drops that one on a length just outside off and that's eased to cover
outside off, arcs away slightly, but it's short enough for the batsman to ease that through the covers
dragged that one down, and that's a crunching cut stroke off the back foot through covers
worked to cover
driven through cover
strides into that one and that's again driven to cover, but straight to the fielder
worked to mid-on
worked to mid-on and Pietersen finds the stumps with a direct hit, but the batsman is well and truly home
defended forward this time
short, doesn't come on as fast as expected, but it's well adjusted and pulled away through midwicket
chipped away behind square and that brings up a well-deserved fifty partnership - 52 from 57 balls
on to the pads but worked to square leg
driven to mid-on
driven to mid-off this time
worked down into the covers
on a good length and that's defended first up

and the move pays off! That's a perfect pitch on leg and turns a touch away as the batsman goes for an aerial drive over cover which he spoons right in the air. A bit of zigzagging from Dalrymple who - importantly - keeps his eye on the ball all the way. Panesar leaps like an exciteable salmon at the catch

that one beats everybody - the batsman and the keeper. Styris went for the sweep shot and Nixon ... what is he doing? He leapt to his left expecting the sweep and, to be fair to him, he would have been there for the catch - but there's an easy few byes
Nixon leaping again... and premature again
pitches that wide to the lefthander who leaves it alone first up
"Cath it" (sic) thayth Nixon through hith mouth guard as Oram gets off the mark with a thweep
round the wicket to the lefthander, short and that's defended down off the back foot into the covers
oh, a nice one there from Flintoff, down the channel and making the batsman fend before pulling out of the shot
two arms, shouldered, as Flintoff swings that a touch away from the lefthander on its way through to Nixon
overpitches a tad and the lefthander stands tall to drive that to mid-on
on the money, coming in at the lefthander from round the wicket, and that's just defending back down the track
worked quietly into midwicket
short and Styris walks over to that one, interested, flaunts his bat, and misses
Monty overcompensates and drags that down leg, tickled round by the batsman
right up there and the batsman gets right over that one in defence
pitches on leg and that's worked into the midwicket area
pitches outside off, that's worked to gully and the batsmen decide to "Wait!"
"How!" says Nixon, pulling out of the lbw appeal as he realises zat's not out; the batsmen profiting from the inside edge
short, wide, and that's worked off the back foot behind point
oh, nearly done up - squared him up and he nearly edges that through
rushes that one past the outside edge and it's snapped up by Nixon
in at the lefthander on a tricky line and that's worked off the back into covers
tries to swerve to avoid the ball and it crashes into his upper left arm and glances past the diving Nixon
worked off the back foot behind point
round the wicket to the lefthander and that's swept behind square
over the wicket to the righthander and that's driven to cover
strides out to that one, an edge falls harmlessly down to slip
swept out to the sweeper on the leg-side boundary
wide, short and that's driven out to Dalrymple on the off-side boundary
defended forward
full, driven crisply to mid-on, not a hope of a run, however
again Styris stands tall and punches the ball straight back down the pitch. Nixon rabbits incessantly to nobody in particular
Plunkett drifts to leg and Styris moves across his stumps and runs the ball down to long leg
a rather contortionist-like wristy whip from outside off stump to square leg
a leading edge which loops a few yards into space and a cry of anguish from the bowler
driven off the pad and then bat into the covers, Plunkett starts to appeal and checks, producing a strange gurgling noise
forward with a dead bat, plopped into the covers and a quick run as Plunkett laboured
squirted behind square on the off, beats the man at point, Bell chases and executes a neat flick back on the rope ... sadly yards wide of his colleague and so the batsmen run an extra one
semi-successful reverse sweep. Many of those have been tried today, few have worked
wide, left alone and it went on with the arm rather than spinning
angled behind square on the off but Bell in like an greyhound
driven out to the sweeper
firm drive straight to point who makes a good stop to his left
on target, driven and misfielded by short midwicket to add to the sloppiness of a no-ball
worked off his hips to long leg
comfortably driven to the man in the deep on the off
pushed from off stump to midwicket
Oram back, waits, and pushes the ball gently into the covers
Oram half forward and angles the ball to point
Styris pushes the ball to the man in the deep on the off ... all a bit sleepy at the moment and the crowd left to amuse themselves ... they need some hitting ...
thank you! Two steps and Oram thunks that over mid-on and it carries the rope by a few feet
steered into the leg side for rather a hurried run
solid defence, all very textbook
dropped into the leg side, again no run as the field closes in quickly
clipped to mid-on who is too deep to save the one
premeditated sweep, more run off the face of the bat than hit
swept from off stump to the man at backward square leg
overpitched, heaved from outside off stump and Pietersen stops the ball on the rope with a sliding stop ... well, he got his hand to the ball but it clipped the rope
mistimed drive, Nixon almost explodes with delight
down the leg side, Nixon demolishes the stumps and the umpire signals the wide
turned into the deep open spaces on the leg side
swept fine and Panesar makes a good, tumbling, sliding stop
gentle loosener outside off stump and a rather limp swish and miss from Oram
driven but not timed, extra cover's hands are hardly stinging after stopping that
a let off for Oram, edged through what would have been first slip's gullet. Anderson is back to take wickets, so surely Vaughan should be attacking?
paddled into space on the off
Styris back and punches that into the covers
good line (78mph) and Styris defends
Oram stands tall and angles that into space behind square on the off
firm drive and a really good sprawling stop by Bell at short midwicket
into space on the leg side for an ambled one
runs almost at will. Collingwood does not have the space so they can pick him off
placed between cover and extra cover. No risks needed and they can pick off six and over. Vaughan needs to apply some pressure
driven hard at Collingwood's feet, he half stops it and the ball cannons into the leg side where it is scooped up
straight drive and mid-on and mid-off almost collide in their eagerness to stop it
spanked into the off side
driven square with a shout of "wait, wait,wait," but it was always a single
full, creamed off the back foot with real power, it splits the covers and the man in the deep is left for dead
too much compensation. leg side, and it goes fine beyond the dive of Nixon
slanted across the left hander and no shot offered
Styris forward and pushes the ball into space
outside the off stump, well wide and the umpire is unimpressed. A harsh call
big, big shout for a catch as Oram pushes forward and it hits the pad and loops up. Nothing doing ...it just didn't look like a catch even thought the appeals were confident.
defended with far less drama
clipped past short midwicket
turned into the leg side, again into wide space and good running to come back for the second
hits him on the pads outside the off stump as he shapes to sweep
loose full toss outside the off stump, steered to the deep
zeroed in on the off stump, solid block
too wide, smacked into the deep on the off side, not much foot movement but he middled it
a cry of exasperation from Flintoff as he beats the outside edge - no movement, pure and simple batsman error
miscued drive, bounces round the stumps and Nixon forced to scurry to retrieve and save the run
speared into the body and no run as Flintoff changes direction quickly to field
dropped into the covers with soft hands, the ball went no more than ten yards but good communication allows a scurried single
good line and length, defended into the covers
flighted and full length, no run. Nixon continues top chat and he is sounding more like Les Dawson with each passing over
lovely placement through the slips, deft touch and it is pulled up a yard from the rope
dropped driven to the right of Pietersen at short extra cover, not hit that hard, and the ball is put down. Not a difficult chance at this level, and that could be the crucial moment
careful and watchful, a quiet end after the drama
on off stump, blocked
short and wide, smacked to the sweeper. A poor ball
oh dear, that started as a wide and carried on getting wider. Flintoff smiles rather like a naughty schoolboy caught in the apple orchard
Oram drives but really doesn't come close to timing that ... he still gets a single though
patted to mid-off
met with a dead bat and the ball struggles to get more than a yard or two towards extra cover
crisp drive to Pietersen at cover
turned round the corner but nothing doing as the man on the 45 races in
worked to midwicket where there is space
little more than a defensive push into space on the off, good placement and another run to chip away at England's resolve
reverse sweep, missed, and the ball cannons off Nixon who grunts and then resumes his stream of comment
full, pushed at short midwicket
played slightly later and squarer, thus allowing an easy single

Oram down the pitch to meet ball and driven to longish-on. The throw from Flintoff is wild and wide of Nixon, nobody is backing up and the ball races away for overthrows. Apologies all round, but that's a surefire sign that England reckon they are done for
real rip, spits down the leg side, turned fine and well stopped
good line again, played well but more turn
pushed past leg slip, Styris wanted two and in the end they came back with comfort
Oram waits and then wristily flicks the ball into the leg side
flighted, steered to Collingwood at slip
pushed to cover, another easy run
bat and pad close together and the ball is played out behind square on the off
exaggerated forward defensive shot. "Find some pink, go for the strawberry," says Nixon. He has clearly not taken his tablets today ... mad as a fruit
fired down the leg side, Nixon can do little about that and the ball shoots to the boundary unmolested
again leg sideish and swept fine
no run, straight to a fielder on the leg side
premeditated sweep to deep backward square leg
good line and length, defended
full, pushed to mid-on
clipped to short midwicket
hit to the same place but a simple stop is botched by Pietersen and the ball bobbles far enough from him to allow the single
low full toss, hit hard to short midwicket where Bell makes a good stop
flighted, dead-batted into the off side and a well-run single. It's the quick singles these two have run which have really sunk England. Death by 1000 cuts ...
outside the off stump, deliberately so, and a wide is called
flicked to long-on, and Nixon calls for two to add to the confusion but the batsmen aren't fooled
plonked into the off side
spins past the laboured lunge and thunks into the pad
Oram brings up his fifty with a clip to mid-on. It has taken 68 balls and has been unspectacular and immensely effective
pushed into the leg side
outside the off stump, Oram twists and watches it on its way
clipped to midwicket, no power however
Vaughan has left a space in the deep on the leg, and Styris takes the bait and thumps the ball with the spin for a two-bounce four right in that region
Dalrymple tosses it up but too wide, Stryis has room to throw his arms at the ball and he cracks it to the cover boundary
the lull after the storm, left alone outside the off stump
turned behind square on the leg side
very cautious defensive stroke into the ground

bat and pad together and into the off side, Pietersen scrambles in from extra cover as the two batsmen suffer indecision, his underarm hits the stumps and all that happens is that the batsmen get an overthrow. It never rains ...
confident drive but right to mid-off
into space behind square on the off side
firm drive to Anderson who is at deep mid-off
slower ball hit to Anderson, and although his throw clatters into the stumps at the bowler's end, Oram was home about 10 seconds earlier
swept with real skill from leg stump down to the long-leg fence
flighted at Oram's feet, a good start
real rip there from KP
pushed to Colingwood at point and his throw almost finds the non-striker short as he was sent back by Oram
played into the off side
turned round the corner for a scurried single

full, Styris almost yorks himself but squeezes the ball to Panesar at mid-on, Panesar winds up for about a second and then from ten yards hurls the ball at Pietersen's feet ... KP jumps to avoid getting one right on the foot
new ball, same result. Steered down to third man from outside off stump
good length, patted back to Plunkett
inside edge into pads, the ball squirms into the off side and the batsmen briefly think of the single but the fielders are closing too fast
beautiful off drive, too full and wide - right in the slot - and Oram hammered that all along the ground past the futile dive of mid-off
clipped to the leg side, they want two and come back for it with comfort
pulled fine, not where it was intended but just as effective, and Panesar dives but can't stop the ball trickling over the boundary. That's that, and the largely English crowd are almost silent ...
